comment.author: 32392332@N03
comment._content:
Estas imágenes guardan un gran valor, por capturar para la posteridad 
una de las tres grandes culturas que ha conocido la humanidad junto con la cultura Maya.

Ojalá ( expresión árabe heredada al español despues de 300 años de ocupación en la península ibérica)  estas fotografías sirvan de reflexión para preservar la vida y las culturas del hombre en el Planeta Tierra, que como vemos, están a punto de extinción.
Una vez que desaparezcan esa impresionantes ruinas son irrecuperables. Lo grave es que el hombre que no tiene pasado, tampoco tiene futuro.

comentario de Mario Hernández Solorio
noviembre / 2008.

comment.author: 9874810@N02
comment._content: I had just the opposite reaction. Just a few minutes after I arrived at the Pyramids a huge sand storm rose up and made for a painful but surreal experience. I did not appreciate the Pyramids at all but not because of the sand storm. The grounds were filthy and the camel and donkey drivers just wouldn't let me alone long enough to take it in. As I sat on a rock trying to grasp the fact that I was sitting at the foot of one of the most recognizable structures in the world, the camel standing next to me urinated and the wind drove his discharge directly onto me :-). But then I walked along a path toward the Sphinx, which, sadly, looks like nothing in this photo and I was unexpectedly quite touched by it.

comment.author: 17350451@N08
comment._content:
The one-metre-wide nose on the face is missing. The Egyptian Arab historian al-Maqrīzī, writing in the fifteenth century CE, attributes the loss to iconoclasm by Muhammad Sa'im al-Dahr, a Sufi Muslim fanatic from the khanqah of Sa'id al-Su'ada. In 1378 CE, upon finding the Egyptian peasants making offerings to the Sphinx in the hope of increasing their harvest, Sa'im al-Dahr was so outraged that he destroyed the nose, and was hanged for vandalism. Al-Maqrīzī describes the Sphinx as the “talisman of the Nile” on which the locals believed the flood cycle depended.

Some legends claim that the nose was broken off by a cannonball fired by Napoléon’s soldiers and that it still survives. Other variants indict British troops, the Mamluks, and others. However, sketches of the Sphinx by the Dane Frederick Lewis Norden, made in 1737 and published in 1755, illustrate the Sphinx already without a nose.

Source Wikipedia
